results_summary: Coenzyme Q10 and selenium supplementation significantly reduced NT-proBNP levels and cardiovascular mortality in participants with baseline NT-proBNP in the second to fourth quintiles, indicating benefits for those with mild to moderate cardiac impairment. No significant effects were observed in other quintiles.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling elderly (mean age 78 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate oxidative stress markers, including Coenzyme Q10 levels, in juvenile fibromyalgia patients and assess the effects of ubiquinol-10 supplementation on these markers and fatigue symptoms.
results_summary: Juvenile fibromyalgia patients showed decreased ubiquinol-10 levels and increased oxidative stress markers. Ubiquinol-10 supplementation (100 mg/day) improved Coenzyme Q10 levels, cholesterol metabolism, and fatigue scores but did not affect free fatty acid levels.
population_specificity: Juvenile fibromyalgia patients (n=10) compared to healthy controls (n=67).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of CoQ10 supplementation on diastolic function in maintenance hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: CoQ10 supplementation significantly reduced intraventricular septum thickness and left ventricle mass, and improved myocardial peak systolic and early diastolic velocities, but did not significantly improve overall diastolic heart function compared to placebo. No significant changes were observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Maintenance hemodialysis patients
study_duration: 8 weeks per phase (with a 4-week washout period)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Coenzyme Q10 supplementation on oxidative stress and antioxidant markers after repeated bouts of supramaximal exercise.
results_summary: Coenzyme Q10 supplementation partially prevented the increase in lipid peroxidation (malondialdehyde) after exercise, while antioxidant markers like uric acid showed changes post-exercise.
population_specificity: Fifteen healthy, sedentary men.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the link between ubiquinol supplementation and changes in gene expression and DNA methylation of pro-inflammatory genes in human monocytes.
results_summary: Ubiquinol supplementation significantly reduced the expression of the pro-inflammatory gene CXCL2 by more than 10-fold and decreased its DNA methylation by 3.4-fold, while also reducing expression of two other pro-inflammatory genes (PMAIP1, MMD) without altering their methylation patterns.
population_specificity: Human volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of rosuvastatin and atorvastatin combined with exercise on Coenzyme Q10 (ubiquinol) and HDL-C levels in CAD patients.
results_summary: Rosuvastatin combined with exercise preserved ubiquinol levels and significantly increased HDL-C and ApoA1 compared to atorvastatin, which decreased ubiquinol levels. Changes in ubiquinol positively correlated with changes in ApoA1.
population_specificity: 28 patients with coronary artery disease (CAD).
interactions: Statins (rosuvastatin and atorvastatin) were noted to interact with Coenzyme Q10 biosynthesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Coenzyme Q10 supplementation on plasma adiponectin, IL-6, and TNF-alpha levels in sedentary men.
results_summary: Coenzyme Q10 supplementation did not significantly affect plasma adiponectin, IL-6, or TNF-alpha levels compared to placebo. Although IL-6 levels increased with CoQ10, the change was not statistically different from placebo.
population_specificity: Fourteen healthy, nonsmoking, sedentary men.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Coenzyme Q10 supplementation improves metabolic parameters, inflammatory markers, arterial stiffness, and fatigue in obese subjects.
results_summary: Coenzyme Q10 supplementation significantly increased serum CoQ10 levels but did not significantly affect lipid profiles, oxidative/inflammatory markers, or arterial stiffness. Fatigue severity scores decreased in the CoQ10 group, but the change was not significantly different from the placebo group.
population_specificity: Obese subjects (BMI ≥25 kg/m²), aged 41–43 years on average.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of oral CoQ10 supplementation on performance during repeated bouts of supramaximal exercise.
results_summary: CoQ10 supplementation showed modest performance-enhancing effects, with increased mean power during the fifth Wingate test and decreased fatigue indexes, though these changes did not significantly differ from placebo. Peak power decreased similarly in both CoQ10 and placebo groups during early tests.
population_specificity: Fifteen healthy, sedentary men.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of robusta coffee husk extract on fibroblast count and collagen density in Wistar rats with P. gingivalis-induced periodontitis.
results_summary: Robusta coffee husk extract at doses of 125, 250, and 500 mg/kgBW increased fibroblast numbers and collagen density in P. gingivalis-induced Wistar rats, with 250 mg/kgBW being the most effective dose.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether coffee pulp (CP) could prevent or ameliorate metabolic syndrome (MetS) in high-fructose-fed rats.
results_summary: CP reduced body weight gain, lowered systolic blood pressure, fasting glucose, and insulin levels, improved insulin resistance, and attenuated hepatic lipid storage and peroxidation in high-fructose-fed rats. It also modulated key genes related to glucose and lipid metabolism in hepatic and adipose tissues.
population_specificity: High-fructose-fed rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of coffee grounds (CG) as bio-fillers and pigments in polymer composites, focusing on dispersion, mechanical properties, and UV aging stability.
results_summary: Silanization of CG improved dispersion and UV aging resistance in polymer composites, with EN/CG-APTS showing the best mechanical properties and EN/BTG-APTS exhibiting the smallest color change after aging.
population_specificity: Polymer composites (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (bio-filler treatment concentrations not detailed).
study_duration: UV aging tested up to 300 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether coffee peel polyphenols (CPPs) could prevent nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) by modulating CB1-ceramide signaling.
results_summary: CPPs significantly improved hepatic steatosis, insulin resistance, and liver function biomarkers in mice. The effects were linked to reductions in endocannabinoid ligands and ceramides, leading to decreased lipogenesis and increased fatty acid oxidation.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice fed a high-fat, high-cholesterol diet.

study_goal: The study does not address Coffee; it examines the effects of a Friendly Visitor program on communication abilities in adults with intellectual disabilities.
results_summary: The study found improvements in pragmatic skills and language production abilities among participants, but these results are unrelated to Coffee.
population_specificity: Four women (27-33 years-old) with mild-to-moderate intellectual disabilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immediate effects of Turkish coffee (60 mg caffeine/65 mL) on postural control and hand-eye coordination in healthy young adults.
results_summary: The study found a significant improvement in postural sway on a firm surface with eyes open and in hand-eye coordination, particularly among male participants, but no significant changes in other balance conditions.
population_specificity: 20 healthy young adults (13 females, 7 males) who were low habitual coffee consumers.
effective_dosage: 65 mL of Turkish coffee (60 mg caffeine).
study_duration: Acute effects measured 30 minutes after ingestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of indaziflam herbicide under different soil cover materials in coffee cultivation, focusing on agronomic efficacy, residual effects, and weed community influence.
results_summary: Indaziflam showed high agronomic efficacy (>90%) until 120 days after application, with residual effects lasting over 180 days. Weed indices were higher without indaziflam, and soil type had a greater impact on weed communities than soil cover.
population_specificity: Coffee cultivation under different soil cover materials (crop debris, organic compost, bare soil) in two farm locations with distinct soil types (sandy clay Oxisol and clay Oxisol).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an eco-friendly method to repurpose spent coffee grounds (SCG) into a superhydrophobic material, avoiding harsh chemicals and energy-intensive processes.
results_summary: The study successfully transformed SCG into a superhydrophobic material with a contact angle of 151° and a rolling-off angle of 8°, demonstrating self-cleaning properties. Solar-induced heating was also shown to activate superhydrophobicity, offering an energy-efficient alternative.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of intercropping Urochloa decumbens with two Arabica coffee cultivars on nutrient levels and coffee crop yield.
results_summary: Intercropping with Urochloa decumbens increased leaf nutrient content (Ca, Mg, Mn, Fe) but did not significantly affect yield overall, except for the 'IPR-99' cultivar, which showed a yield increase of 400 kg ha-1. The system improved nutrient cycling and efficiency for coffee plants.
population_specificity: Arabica coffee plants (cultivars 'IPR-103' and 'IPR-99') intercropped with Urochloa decumbens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare performance-enhancement expectations for coffee versus energy drinks using the Stanford Expectations of Treatment Scale.
results_summary: Participants had significantly higher positive expectations for coffee compared to energy drinks, suggesting coffee is perceived as a more effective performance enhancer with greater placebo-inducing potential. Negative expectations were more pronounced for energy drinks than coffee.
population_specificity: 402 participants (48.5% male) with an average exercise history of 4.53 years, engaging in physical activity 3.91 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between statin use and decreased CoQ10 levels, and whether CoQ10 supplementation improves statin-related myopathy symptoms and serum CoQ10 levels.
results_summary: The review found that statin use significantly reduces serum CoQ10 levels, and some studies showed symptomatic improvement in myalgia or increased CoQ10 levels with supplementation, though one study reported no benefit. No risks of supplementation were reported.
population_specificity: Patients taking statins and experiencing statin-induced myopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate atractyligenin derivatives as biomarkers for coffee consumption and assess their presence in plasma and urine after coffee intake.
results_summary: The study found that atractyligenin and its 19-O-β-D-glucuronide were reliable markers of coffee consumption in plasma and urine, detectable for up to 24 hours after intake, with no significant differences based on brewing method or gender. Other metabolites were inconsistent and unreliable as indicators.
population_specificity: 12 participants (6 female, 6 male) in a coffee intervention study.
study_duration: 3 days of coffee abstinence followed by coffee consumption with monitoring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of regular coffee intake in preventing or treating COVID-19 and explore its potential mechanism of action using molecular docking.
results_summary: The study found that drinking more than 1 cup of coffee per day was associated with higher benefit rates, including lower COVID-19 infection rates and improved recovery rates. Molecular docking suggested that compounds in coffee (CGA and caffeine) may interact with key proteins (ACE2 and 3CL) involved in COVID-19.
population_specificity: 39,290 participants across 5 studies (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of biochar derived from spent coffee as an adsorbent for removing organic pollutants from wastewater.
results_summary: The study found that biochar from spent coffee, activated with MgCO3, achieved high removal efficiencies (up to 100%) for various organic pollutants, including dyes, pharmaceuticals, and xenoestrogens, depending on solution pH. The biochar exhibited enhanced surface area and porosity, making it highly effective for wastewater treatment.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study on wastewater treatment, not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on adsorbent material, not human consumption).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial efficacy of Coffea arabica and Coffea canephora (Robusta) extracts as intracanal irrigants in endodontic therapy.
results_summary: Green Robusta extracts showed antimicrobial effectiveness at concentrations of 25% and 12.5%, with Robusta green 12.5% extract demonstrating sustained efficacy comparable to sodium hypochlorite. All coffee extract groups significantly reduced microbial counts compared to the negative control.
population_specificity: Extracted human single-rooted teeth (70 samples).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to extract and evaluate the structural, compositional, and functional properties of coffee peel soluble dietary fiber (CSDF) using ultrasound-assisted alcohol precipitation to reduce waste and environmental pollution.
results_summary: Ultrasonic treatment reduced CSDF particle size, improved homogeneity, and enhanced thermal stability, water-solubility, oil-holding, and water-holding capacities. It also increased glucose and nitrite ion adsorption capacities, suggesting potential food industry applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory effects of spent coffee ground extract (SCGE) on biofilm formation in *Listeria monocytogenes* and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: SCGE disrupted biofilm formation and architecture in *L. monocytogenes*, reduced autoaggregation and surface hydrophobicity, downregulated motility- and adhesion-related genes, impaired swimming motility, and suppressed quorum sensing signaling. However, SCGE did not affect the viability of planktonic *L. monocytogenes*.
population_specificity: *Listeria monocytogenes* (pathogenic bacteria)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of extracting mannooligosaccharides (MO) from spent coffee grounds (SCG) and evaluating their functional properties in jelly, including antioxidant activity, α-glucosidase inhibition, and immunomodulatory effects.
results_summary: The study found that combinational enzyme treatment with pectinase and mannanase significantly improved CMO yield (6.8 times higher than mannanase alone) and extraction efficiency (70%). CMO20 jelly demonstrated superior stability, functional properties, antioxidant activity, and α-glucosidase inhibition (48% greater than acarbose), along with enhanced immunomodulatory effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using RAW264.7 cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the bactericidal effect of naringenin (NG) and its synergistic effect with mild heat (MH) treatment in cold brew coffee against foodborne pathogens.
results_summary: The study found that 10 mM NG combined with MH treatment at 50°C resulted in significant pathogen inactivation (5-8-log reduction) in cold brew coffee, with minimal impact on quality attributes like pH, color, and phenolic content. NG or MH alone had marginal effects.
population_specificity: Foodborne pathogens (Escherichia coli O157:H7, Salmonella Typhimurium, Listeria monocytogenes, Staphylococcus aureus) in ready-to-drink cold brew coffee.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a detection system for coffee leaf rust (CLR) using YOLOv5 and YOLOv8 models to improve pruning efficiency and pesticide application in coffee plantations.
results_summary: The study found that YOLOv8 outperformed YOLOv5 in detecting coffee leaf rust, achieving a mean average precision (mAP) of 73.2% compared to YOLOv5's 70.5%. The system was successfully deployed for real-time detection and integrated into pruning solutions for Arabica coffee farms.
population_specificity: Coffee plantations in Majalengka Regency, Indonesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether coffee consumption improves bowel movement recovery in women after cesarean section surgery.
results_summary: The study found that coffee significantly improved bowel movement recovery (timing of bowel sounds, first gas passage, and first defecation) compared to warm water, though hospitalization length did not differ between groups.
population_specificity: 200 women who underwent cesarean section in two hospitals.
effective_dosage: 100 cc of coffee at 8, 12, 24 hours post-surgery.

study_goal: The study aimed to explore medical students' perceptions and experiences regarding the surgery clerkship and surgeons, not Coffee.
results_summary: The study found that stereotypes about surgeons and surgical clerkships were prevalent among medical students, with negative perceptions decreasing and interest in surgical careers increasing post-clerkship. Poor supervision and feedback were noted as negative experiences.
population_specificity: Medical students at Erasmus Medical Center entering a surgery education block and clerkship.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic coffee consumption affects cardiovascular and total mortality in hypertensive patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in cardiovascular or total mortality between coffee consumers and non-consumers in hypertensive patients, regardless of blood pressure measurements or antihypertensive treatment status.
population_specificity: 943 hypertensive patients from the PAMELA study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a lytic phage cocktail encapsulated in chitosan-coated Ca-alginate nanoparticles for controlling bacterial halo blight (BHB) caused by Pseudomonas coronafaciens pv. garcae in coffee plants.
results_summary: The phage cocktail reduced disease severity by 66.83% to 83.37%, depending on application timing, and nanoencapsulation stabilized the phages against UV radiation. The treatment showed promise as an alternative to chemical or biological agents for BHB control.
population_specificity: Coffee plants infected with Pseudomonas coronafaciens pv. garcae.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether spent coffee grounds and tea residues could be transformed into porous materials for environmental remediation, specifically for removing marine micropollutants.
results_summary: The study found that the synthesized material achieved up to 99.62% removal of tetracycline (TC) and demonstrated strong adsorption capacity for marine microplastics and radioactive pollutants. The approach showed high efficiency in wastewater treatment.
population_specificity: Environmental pollutants (antibiotic wastewater, radioactive pollutants, microplastics)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare methods for extracting cellulose from spent ground coffee and characterize the extracted cellulose's properties.
results_summary: The study found that nitric acid-sodium chlorite and sodium chlorite with alkali pre-treatments yielded the highest cellulose content (96.7%) and whiteness index (71.24). Hydrogen peroxide treatment with alkali pre-treatment increased crystallinity index (from 54.9% to 66.3%) and thermal stability (degradation temperature from 292.0 to 310.5°C).
population_specificity: Spent ground coffee (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (chemical treatments described but not in dosage terms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-temperature pasteurization using induced electric field (IEF) versus high-temperature short-time (HTST) pasteurization on the chemical properties, flavor, and microbial safety of cold brew coffee during storage.
results_summary: The study found that IEF treatment at 58°C achieved effective microbial reduction while preserving key aroma compounds, particularly pyrazine compounds, and maintained total sugar and phenol content better than HTST pasteurization. Bioactive compounds initially increased but later decreased during storage.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory analysis of cold brew coffee samples).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (processing conditions: IEF at 52°C and 58°C for 92s, HTST at 93°C for 2min).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of controlled coffee consumption on erythrocyte functional status in healthy young adults.
results_summary: The study found that coffee consumption improved erythrocyte deformability, increased Na,K-ATPase activity, enhanced nitric oxide production, and shifted antioxidant balance favorably, though changes were modest. Body composition remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 33 healthy young volunteers
effective_dosage: Standardized dose daily (exact amount not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether coffee-derived exosome-like nanoparticles (CDELNs) could treat or prevent amyloid-β-induced Alzheimer's disease by protecting neuronal cells from toxicity.
results_summary: CDELNs significantly increased the viability of Aβ(1-42)-toxicity-induced HT-22 cells and restored mitochondrial membrane potential, suggesting neuroprotective effects against Aβ-induced neurotoxicity.
population_specificity: Mouse hippocampal neuronal cells (HT-22) in an in vitro Alzheimer's model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of different pretreatments on spent coffee grounds (SCG) for biofuels and value-added product generation, focusing on biomolecule release, H2 potential, and volatile fatty acids production.
results_summary: The study found that alkaline-pretreated SCG slurry at 23.3 g VS/L yielded the highest H2 production (25-30 mL H2/g VS), while higher VS concentrations (46.7 g VS/L) inhibited H2 production due to excessive NaOH use. Ultrasound-pretreated SCG achieved high volatile fatty acids accumulation (3260.0 mg HAceq/L at 46.7 g VS/L).
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study on spent coffee grounds, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of green coffee supplementation on PON-1 activity and MDA levels in women with PCOS.
results_summary: Green coffee supplementation significantly increased PON-1 levels and reduced cholesterol and triglyceride levels, but had no significant impact on MDA levels or glycemic markers.
population_specificity: 44 women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
effective_dosage: 400 mg of green coffee supplements daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether superhydrophobic microstructured grooved substrates could mitigate the coffee ring effect (CRE) and enhance the stability and accuracy of laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) for heavy metal detection.
results_summary: The study found that superhydrophobic microstructured grooved substrates effectively mitigated the CRE, reducing spectral intensity variability (RSD of 3.6% vs. 25.4% for unstructured substrates) and improving detection sensitivity (LODs of 0.16 μg mL-1 and 0.11 μg mL-1) and prediction accuracy (R2 of 0.994 and 0.995 for Sr).
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study on substrate performance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how nanosilicon and seaweed extracts improve Arabica coffee plant resilience during heat stress by maintaining mineral homeostasis and photosynthetic ability.
results_summary: The study found that nanosilicon (Si) and seaweed extract (SWE), especially when combined, improved magnesium-silicon homeostasis, preserved chlorophyll content, and restored photosynthetic efficiency in Arabica coffee plants under heat stress.
population_specificity: Arabica coffee plants subjected to heat stress (49.0 ± 0.3 °C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an economic-epidemiological model to assess the impact of coffee leaf rust on coffee farms and evaluate the economic feasibility of intervention policies.
results_summary: The study found that without directly addressing the rust pandemic, sustaining profit is economically impractical. Even with perfect knowledge of farm conditions, efforts yield only a 4% profit, while realistic scenarios predict economic losses, indicating potential market disturbances.
population_specificity: Coffee farms in Colombia, primarily small-scale operations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of processed coffee husk on feed intake, nutrient digestibility, body weight changes, and profitability in Bonga rams.
results_summary: Boiled coffee husk (T2) significantly improved dry matter intake, nutrient digestibility, and body weight gain compared to raw or roasted coffee husk, without adverse effects from anti-nutritional factors.
population_specificity: Bonga rams (mean initial body weight 21.5 ± 1.01 kg).
effective_dosage: 200 g boiled coffee husk + 200 g conventional concentrate mix (1:1 ratio).
study_duration: 90-day experimental period followed by a 7-day digestibility trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effects of coffee and other beverages on weight loss in adults.
results_summary: The study found that coffee (including decaffeinated and green coffee) was not effective for weight loss compared to placebo or water, based on the analyzed trials. No significant weight loss effects were observed for coffee in the study.
population_specificity: Adults (excluding critically ill patients, pregnant or breastfeeding women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of countercurrent ultrasound on the extraction efficiency, quality, and flavor of cold brew coffee compared to traditional extraction methods.
results_summary: Ultrasonic-assisted extraction (UE) improved efficiency by 83.33%, matching the total dissolved solids and extraction yield of a 5-hour traditional extraction. UE also increased polyphenols, sugars, and lipids while reducing acids, with similar flavor components to traditional extraction.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on coffee extraction).
effective_dosage: Dual-frequency 20/28 kHz, 50 min ultrasonic treatment, 320 W/L power density, material-liquid ratio 1:15.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of purified cafestol on insulin sensitivity and metabolic parameters in individuals at risk of type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Cafestol did not improve insulin sensitivity or glucose tolerance but significantly reduced body weight (2%), visceral fat volume (5%), and gamma-glutamyl transferase levels (15%) compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals with increased waist circumference at risk of developing type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the relationship between chlorogenic acids (CGA) from coffee and cognitive performance and conduct a meta-analysis of relevant RCTs.
results_summary: The systematic review suggested chronic CGA consumption from coffee might benefit cognition, but the meta-analysis of RCTs showed no significant cognitive benefits (d = 0.00). Limited studies, small sample sizes, and varied cognitive measures indicate a need for further research.
population_specificity: Human participants (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of coffee roasting degree on antioxidant capacity, metabolic parameters, and effects on carbohydrate and lipid metabolism in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Increased roasting reduced antioxidant capacity in vitro but improved metabolic outcomes in vivo, including reduced postprandial glucose, serum triglycerides, weight gain, adipocyte volume, and lipid peroxidation, with high-roast coffee showing notable benefits.
population_specificity: Healthy rats and a diet-induced obesity rat model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of green coffee bean extract (GCBE) consumption on systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), and heart rate (HR) in adults.
results_summary: GCBE consumption significantly decreased SBP and DBP but had no significant effect on HR. The effect was more pronounced in participants with high baseline blood pressure and showed no effect in females. No significant dose-response relationship was found.
population_specificity: Adults, with subgroup analysis for hypertensive individuals and females.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether restricting coffee consumption has a beneficial effect on Ménière's disease (MD) symptoms.
results_summary: The study found no significant correlation between coffee consumption and MD, with an odds ratio of 0.852 (95% CI: 0.555-1.306; p = 0.461). Reverse analysis also showed no evidence of MD affecting coffee consumption.
population_specificity: Up to 941,280 participants from the United Kingdom Biobank, GSCAN, and the FinnGen study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of the "SHe CoFFEE" home-based online exercise program on improving mobility in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvement in mobility (measured by TUG test) compared to the control group at 8 weeks, with similar results in per-protocol analysis. Secondary outcomes, except quality of life, also improved more in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling seniors (60 participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise program, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an eco-friendly, cost-effective biochar-zeolite composite (BZC) from waste materials (spent coffee grounds and steel slag) for wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The BZC showed high dye removal efficiency (95% for general dyes, 97% for methyl orange, and 99.53% for crystal violet) and maintained effectiveness over multiple regeneration cycles, though phosphate removal decreased from 92% to 70% by the third cycle.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study on wastewater treatment).
study_duration: Not specified (kinetic studies reached equilibrium in 2 hours).

study_goal: The researchers were not studying Coffee; the abstract focuses on the role of immunoproteasome in anti-tumor immune responses and its potential as a target for cancer immunotherapy.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention Coffee or its effects; it discusses immunoproteasome's role in immune responses, therapeutic potential of its inhibitors, and challenges in clinical translation.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study does not involve Coffee)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether KOH-activated coffee grounds (KACGs) could effectively adsorb organophosphorus pesticides (malathion and chlorpyrifos) from water, offering a sustainable solution for biowaste management and water remediation.
results_summary: KACGs demonstrated rapid adsorption kinetics and high affinity for chlorpyrifos and malathion, with higher adsorption capacity for chlorpyrifos (22.3 mg g-1) than malathion (15.0 mg g-1). The process was spontaneous, and no toxic byproducts were formed, indicating potential for reducing neurotoxic risks from pesticide exposure.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using water samples contaminated with pesticides).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (adsorbent material used, not a dosage-based intervention).
study_duration: Not specified (kinetics and isotherm studies typically involve short-term experimental durations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of spent coffee ground biochar (SCGB) as an adsorbent for removing methylene blue (MB) from wastewater.
results_summary: The study found that SCGB achieved 99.99% MB removal under optimal conditions (0.99 g SCGB, 30 min contact time, 30 °C, pH 7), with strong model validation and high adsorption capacity.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on wastewater treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of lightly roasted coffee (LRC) and roasted coffee (RC) on body composition and metabolic syndrome-related variables in overweight individuals.
results_summary: Both LRC and RC reduced fat mass and body fat percentage while slightly increasing muscle mass, with LRC showing a greater reduction in fat percentage. No significant changes were observed in metabolic syndrome variables or body weight.
population_specificity: 60 participants with a BMI between 25 and 35 kg/m² and a median age of 51.0 years.
effective_dosage: Three 200 mL cups/day of either LRC (≈400 mg hydroxycinnamic acids, ≈130 mg caffeine) or RC (≈150 mg hydroxycinnamic acids, ≈70 mg caffeine).
study_duration: 12 weeks per coffee type, with 2-week wash-out periods between interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Turkish coffee on breast cancer pathways, including apoptosis, proliferation, and oxidative stress, in both in vitro and in vivo models.
results_summary: Coffee extract significantly increased Caspase-8, P-glycoprotein, and PPAR-γ protein levels in MCF-7 cells and reduced tumor volume, weight, and viable cell density in mice. It also decreased β-catenin and MDA levels while increasing necrotic zones.
population_specificity: Human breast cancer cell line (MCF-7) and mice with induced Ehrlich solid tumors.
effective_dosage: In vitro: 5% or 10% v/v coffee extract; in vivo: 3%, 5%, or 10% v/v in drinking water daily.
study_duration: 48 hours in vitro; 21 days in vivo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent studies on micronutrient imbalances, including copper, in patients with alcoholic liver disease (ALD) and determine their role in ALD pathophysiology.
results_summary: The study found mixed results for copper, with both elevation and deficiency observed in existing literature, highlighting inconsistencies in its role in ALD.
population_specificity: Patients with alcoholic liver disease (ALD).
